SessionedTextBox.name: Label
SessionedTextBox.htmlText:
United States NREL Wind Energy Capacity

This visualization shows data relating to on shore and off shore wind capacity in the United States. Since wind is one of the fastest growing energy sectors in the United States, it is important to choose the best sites for wind energy based on state capacity. The data in this visualization comes from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory in a June 2010 report titled "Assessment of Off-Shore Wind Energy Resources of the United States" as well as from the Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy. The visualization includes data from the lower 48 contiguous states; however, off-shore data from Florida, Alabama, and Mississippi were not available for this visualization. The off-shore sites shown in the coastal areas adjacent to each coastal state includes an area between 3-50 nautical miles off the coast of these states.

Each state is colored based on the off shore and on shore available wind resource capacity available in megawatts. By default the visualization?s colors show the Total Potential Capacity Off Shore and On Shore but by selecting the Wrench icon in the upper left hand corner of the map box, the user may turn on other layers showing additional information. By selecting the visible box next to the USoildPlatforms layer, the map will show 4000+ points representing oil rigs off the Texas, Louisiana, California, Mississippi, and Alabama. Additionally, by selecting the visible check box next to the WT_FAAOE_2000_2011 layer, over 90,000 points will be displayed representing the Federal Aviation Administration?s Obstruction Evaluations for wind turbines 2000-2011. These points represent proposed and existing wind turbines which stand over 200 feet.
